holidays.name: National Espresso Day
holidays.description: A day to honor the bold, concentrated coffee shot that energizes millions worldwide. Perfect excuse to indulge in an espresso or try making your own shot at home.
holidays.origin: Originated from Italian coffee culture celebrations and popularized globally by coffee enthusiasts.
holidays.funFact: Espresso isn‚Äôt a type of coffee bean or roast ‚Äî it‚Äôs a brewing method that uses pressure to make that small, strong cup!

holidays.name: Parade Day (Washington, D.C.)
holidays.description: The annual day commemorating the inauguration parades in Washington, D.C., celebrated with quirky mini-parades and community festivities.
holidays.origin: Inspired by the grand inaugural parades and adapted by locals as a fun, unofficial celebration day.
holidays.funFact: The first presidential inaugural parade in D.C. happened in 1805 for Thomas Jefferson‚Äôs second term.

holidays.name: Fibonacci Day (Unofficial)
holidays.description: A celebration of the famous Fibonacci sequence where each number is the sum of the two preceding ones, reflecting patterns found in nature.
holidays.origin: Coined by math enthusiasts to honor Italian mathematician Leonardo Fibonacci.
holidays.funFact: Sunflower seed patterns and pinecones often mirror Fibonacci numbers in their spirals!

holidays.name: National Die Crazy Day
holidays.description: A quirky day to embrace your inner gamer and enjoy board games, dice games, or even craft your own dice sets.
holidays.origin: Emerged from gaming communities as a fun way to celebrate dice‚Äôs role in games old and new.
holidays.funFact: Dice have been used for gaming and divination for over 5,000 years, making them truly timeless!
